author: WelpSigh
body:
Not great. UFC has a deal with ESPN that guarantees minimum revenue for most of its cards. Its growth is largely priced in, you aren't going to see an unexpected surge in profit. Audiences are not a huge part of their revenue, which is why their shares soared during the pandemic. UFC revenues are also volatile - a fighter getting COVID, for example, can cause a PPV to collapse, costing the company millions. This happened with Khamzat and it's unclear if he will ever be the same fighter again (he retired due to long covid then un-retired after Dana and the president of his country convinced him to try again). Several cards this year have been cursed like this, and the risks increase as UFC is under pressure to put up more events to meet the terms of the ESPN agreement. UFC is also undergoing a number of pay disputes with fighters that risks the viability of the business should it significantly worsen - for example, the expected Ngannou v. Jones superfight looks off the table for the foreseeable future.

Other risks include ESPN moving away from MMA - UFC got a very good, 5 year deal from them as Disney wants to use MMA to drive subscriptions to their paywalled ESPN+ streaming service. They may not get such a good deal when this is re-negotiated and ESPN has significantly more leverage to dictate the terms. Moreover, UFC's non-paywalled content has largely gotten mediocre ratings.

Finally, Endeavor is not just UFC. It's a huge holding company. A quick Google shows UFC's group makes up only about a quarter of their revenue. While that is an important asset, you aren't just buying UFC here - you see also holding stinkers like Miss Universe.

body:
these Mods are killing me. I did an solid and honest DD about MVST it got taken down 2 times. 

FYI: As some of you know Oshkosh is a large investor in Microvast and is currently being sued in claims court by Workhorse over the USPS NGDV. This is a contract to manufacture up to 165000 (EV:ice) mail trucks. It is our understanding that next week (possibly Monday) a ruling on a proposed protest dismissal will take place.

(Microvast will be providing batteries for EV.)

[https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210205005089/en/Microvast-Enters-Electrification-Joint-Development-Agreement-With-Oshkosh-Corporation](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210205005089/en/Microvast-Enters-Electrification-Joint-Development-Agreement-With-Oshkosh-Corporation)

[https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/59991147/workhorse-group-inc-v-united-states/?filed\_after=&filed\_before=&entry\_gte=&entry\_lte=&order\_by=desc](https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/59991147/workhorse-group-inc-v-united-states/?filed_after=&filed_before=&entry_gte=&entry_lte=&order_by=desc)

If protest is dismissed it will be Good for both Oshkosh and Microvast. I’m not a lawyer but the USPS/Oshkosh argument sounds solid. Workhorse broke rules, then sued saying rules were wrong.

“By filing this protest, Workhorse is telling the Court and the parties that the normal rules do not apply to Workhorse. This is wrong. Workhorse, like any other company that wants to do business with the USPS, is required to complete the USPS’s mandatory disagreement process before going to Court. author: TeachingWealth
body:
5 yr projections: 25% avg Rev Growth YoY, 0% Share Change avg, 25% FCF margin, 15 P/FCF Multiple in 2026, 10% Discount Rate = $366.93 fair value. As a U.S. investor with a small chance of the $BABA ADR being removed from U.S. markets and me personally having no way of buying on the HK exchange, I want a 40% margin of safety. Gives me a personal buy price of $220.16. I built a position that ended up being cost basis of $199.03 and I'm content with that on a risk v reward perspective. 

31% growth rate yoy avg for 5 years is nigh impossible and certainly not what I would input as my base case evaluation. Its already a 521 Billion market cap company and that's at its current undervalued price, in reality its around 700+ Billion when fairly value. To grow at 31% avg for the next 5 years at that size is quite unlikely, even before accounting for the governmental risk they face.

author: stenlis
body:
> legit to me is the fact that >30% of the USD was printed past 2 years.  

You need to learn about fractional reserve banking, because this is how so much USD "got printed" in the past two years. The nature of the currency would change nothing. Even if the US was full on crypto, it would have still risen by 30 percent, because fractional reserve banking enables multiple people to own the same coin (unwittingly). 

See this explanation demonstrating the principle with gold coins as basis.

https://www.khanacademy.org/economics-finance-domain/macroeconomics/monetary-system-topic/macro-banking-and-the-expansion-of-the-money-supply/v/overview-of-fractional-reserve-banking

author: tpjoynt
body:
whoa

Let me explain processors. You have designs imposed on top of transistors. The meme stocks of the day, Nvidia, AMD - they just *design chips*, but do not manufacture them, so they're all contracting out to fabs (which hurt margins), the cutting edge of today being taiwan semi. AMD is yielding off of old Keller designs and nvidia has cuda for crypto / etc., but neither of those are moats

Here's a list of all the semicounductor fabs in the world: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List\_of\_semiconductor\_fabrication\_plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_semiconductor_fabrication_plants)

Most of them fucking suck in terms of density, because, most things aren't iPhones and don't need cutting edge nodes (cough cars cough cough).

But, if you'll notice, intel isn't *that* far behind. In fact, they're among the closest to taiwan semi, and we get into niche things like 7nm not really being 7nm (it's more about transistor density, where intel 10 is close to taiwan 7, etc.)

And in terms of durable competitive advantage - chip fabs are like nuclear reactors, highly capital intensive, highly complicated, hard to run == giant moat.

For value investors, you buy from pessimists, and intel pessimists follow jimmy crames saying they don't have 7nm, while Pat is investing 20 billion in new fabs building out that moat. Even if they fab crappier chips there's a shortage, companies that need chips (like fucking everything) will buy from intel if it's attractive. Also USA national interest won't let intel go under, especially with the alternative consolidating into taiwan  
That's not to mention the top line consumer initiatives like their new GPU line and continuing processor line, which could adapt to RISC-V / ARM if needed (they have the cash flow for R&D to do it).

body:
*That is called marketing. Nothing more.*

NFTs and cryptocurrencies might use similar tech, but they're fundamentally different concepts.

Do you think Visa would buy physical artworks as an investment? Why would a digital one be any different? They're paying for headlines, not the NFT.

This is a good indicator of their stance on crypto though. This is presumably meant to make people associate their brand with crypto, which is honestly a pretty bold step for a company that would generally be thought of as just being a well-established and boring monolith.

author: SCHNiiiiKEN
body:
There is a translation that was done of the video.  I will paste it here.  

There is also a slide in an old investor deck showing thorough fire testing and penetration testing (slide 13 here: http://chargedevs.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Microvast-201406-LpTO-Battery-Introduction-Charged-EV.pdf

And here is the translation of the russian penetration test YouTube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tW4x_BTTwUY

00:00-00:42
We are e-bike lovers. The Poltava company Prom Elektronika begins to use Microvast cells in its batteries, from which it will collect powerful and not so expensive batteries. This is a new technology that the vendor claims to be very successful. Why is it interesting? It is interesting because these elements are presented by the manufacturer as elements that can withstand about 7.000 charge-discharge cycles. This plate has a charging current up to 20 amps. This plate has a discharge current of up to 60 amperes.
00:42-01:12
This plate is not very big, as you can see. It is easy to install and, most importantly, according to the statement of our suppliers and according to the passport that we have, this plate does not burn during crash tests. Now we will carry out crash tests of this plate and try to check how true this is. I mean will it burn or not.
01:12-01:56
Now we take this plate. I feel terribly sorry to crash it, but in order to make sure that this is true, we have to destroy one plate because we love to check everything and to be convinced of everything ourselves. That is, we take the plate and lay it down. We have seen many times how li-ion elements burn, and we cannot extinguish them. We take, well, we find some penetrating object. Give us this thing and now we will try to break through this plate in some place with a blow.
01:56-02:31
This plate is broken, and so far we do not see a fire. We don't even see any warming here. That is, in principle, I would like to leave the element for a few minutes so that it stands.
02:31-02:46 
If it was an ordinary Li-ion plate, it would have already caught fire through the penetration of this thing.
02:46-03:22
We'll take it now. Please give me this tube again. Now we will take another test method. Let's try to destroy our plate this way.
03:22-03:59
We see that it does not want to burn. Give me one more time. The plate stubbornly refuses to burn. There is no fire, no heating.
04:01-04:32
Well, what can I say, I think that this plate will be a very good solution for our batteries, since believe me, the safety of our cells is very important. Here you can watch our influences, traces of penetration, breakdown, everything is there, everything is whole. Thank you for your attention.
04:32-04:57
Now we will try to make one more test. Let’s see how it resists. We brought here a fully charged plate, and as you can see, it has already been welded. That is, despite the fact that we pierced it, despite the fact that we crashed it, it is still trying to work.
04:59-05:42
It is short-circuited, let's wait now, will there be a fire now, because if the batteries are usually so short-circuited, they usually burn. This plate, as you can see, became warm. Despite the fact that we pierced it, it is trying to work. I will repeat, we brought here a fully charged plate. Notice how it burned out because it works, plate was fully charged for up to 19 amp / hours.
05:42-06:03
Well, you see how. The ability to perform is shown, the penetrations are shown, and the endurance of short circuit shown. I think this will be a very great offer for our consumers and we will try to make wide use of it. Thanks.
06:03-06:49
Well then. That is, we short-circuited this plate, you saw how, with the help of this pipe. Here are the results of our welding this plate to the pipe. You see, our output contacts are burnt on this plate, they are almost completely burnt out. The plate is hot. Well, it's warm, but I can hold it in my hands. That is, here the degrees are between 40-50-60 c. Well, in principle, there is nothing burning. That is, we punched it twice, we short-circuited it. The plate passed all the tests that were written in the passport.

author: shortyafter
body:
I get the honor and the pleasure of being the first with this video from Jim Cramer in August 2007 that I stumbled upon.  Worth a watch for anyone interested in the 2007/08 Global Financial Crisis:

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rOVXh4xM-Ww](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rOVXh4xM-Ww)

Context: Two Bear Stearns hedge funds have collapsed and French bank BNS Paribas has frozen deposits and expressed doubt about the market for US asset-backed securities.  Fed chair Ben Bernanke is more worried about inflation than providing liquidity to the market and Cramer gives him a piece of his mind.

I looked this up while reading Bernanke's book *The Courage to Act* where he mentions the episode.  Apparently he didn't watch the clip.

Not using this to say "omg a crash is coming", just found it to be an interesting piece of financial history.  I don't really like Mr. Cramer but do feel his critique of Bernanke being out of touch with the real world was valid at the time.  I also feel that a similar critique could be made towards Jay Powell nowadays.  Politics and speculation aside, however, I think the video is worth a watch just to see how crazy things were back then.

([Cramer's comments](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGwgKqTKMFQ) on the episode 10 years later are worth a watch, too)

author: GraysonMA
body:
When you buy leaps you are taking on a lot of vega exposure which can add significant risk to your portfolio. However, vega gives you a second way to win if you stick to companies that have IVR/IV% near their 52 week lows. [Barchart is a great resource for finding these.](https://www.barchart.com/options/iv-rank-percentile/stocks?orderBy=optionsWeightedImpliedVolatility&orderDir=asc)
I also choose underlyings that have low correlation with each other. This keeps things a little less volatile which is especially important using any type of leverage. [PortfolioVisualizer has a great tool for this.](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=SPY+TLT+KO+PG+D+INTC+MCD+VZ+FB+MSFT+NVDA+LLY+NEE&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36). Leaps I bought recently are in PG, INTC, FB, D, MSFT, KO, VZ, and MCD. LLY is an solid low correlation pick but I’m waiting for a dip in IV.

author: Summebride
body:
Stocks means stock market securities that you've surely heard of, Microsoft, Intel, JP Morgan, etc.

Bonds are a timed instrument where you lend your money to something and they pay it back later, with a slight amount extra.

Bonds have traditionally been for old people as they neither go up or down very much, and are predictable.  

Stocks can change in value radically and have traditionally been recommended for young  people so if you lose a lot of value, you have time to make it up.  

Blended fund just means a mix of those two kinds of things.  

At 23 there's no other choice than stock.  

AAR% likely means average annual return.  So if the AAR% was 4% and you have 1000 placed there, it would have gained about $40 during the year.  

Bunds are have recently been returning close to nothing.  Someday that might change but for now they're pretty much a worthless option for you.

author: vansterdam_city
body:
There are a lot of dividend related posts today but this might be the dumbest.

A good dividend stock is something that you see a basically infinite time horizon for (let’s say 30 years). Coca Cola 30 years ago is a classic example, its a product that doesn’t change much and was likely be enjoyed by people for decades to come. 

Technology is by nature prone to innovative disruption. This is horrible for the prospects of a dividend paying company. I couldn’t think of a worse two words to pair together on an investment choice. 

Technology is for GROWTH as you disrupt the market. Buying into the mature end of the cycle is right when you are prone to being disrupted yourself by a new player. 

Some of your picks like Intel and Cisco could easily be disrupted and become dinosaurs. For a measly 2%-ish dividend? You have to be kidding me to think this is a sane investment thesis.

author: shortyafter
body:
You don't have anything like Tesla or ARK funds, which is good.  I'm not deeply familiar with most of these companies, so I don't know what their revenue streams or growth prospects look like.  What I can say is that a lot of those names have been trading very high lately... AMD, Nvidia, TSM, ASML, etc. Those companies in particular all seem to have bright futures, but if there is any significant correction in tech stocks, you're very exposed, especially if you bought recently at high valuations.  You'll have very little margin of safety.

And if there's any broader economic disruption, it's possible that not all of these companies make it out safe and sound, or at least as healthy as you'd like to seem them given current valuations.

For example, even good companies like Cisco didn't make it out in one piece from the dot-com bubble.  And old industry leaders like IBM and Intel have gotten hammered in the past two decades, while Microsoft made something of a surprise comeback after being declared dead around 2012.

The point is that if you've bought growth stories, that's OK, but it seems your whole portfolio is growth stories.  It's forward-looking.  Which is the idea, in a way, but IMO you want at least some of your portfolio dedicated to something that is solid in the present, and doesn't rely on a growth story in order to generate or even maintain returns.  The benefit of an ETF is you get a bit of everything, and even QQQ is quite diversified compared to your portfolio.  

I'm new but this is my understanding of things.  I hope it made sense.

author: beefstake
body:
Less bad then you might think. Most people fundamentally misunderstand what caused the supply crunch thus fundamentally misunderstand who is adversely affected.

Covid didn't suddenly cause a massive spike in demand in order to precipitate a crunch. There was some demand increase in consumer electronics sector as more people purchased equipement to work from home but this is rather minimal and mostly focused on products that people didn't already have and are using lower end semiconductor processes, think webcams, mice, keyboards. Take a look at LOGI to see how this side of the demand increase played out.

Now, so what -actually- caused the supply crunch? Well actually it was automakers and other traditional industries that forecasted a massive decrease in demand cancelling or scaling back their supply contracts. This caused foundries to either spin down for retool or sell capacity to someone else. Both are having a significant impact on auto chips right now which are mostly produced on the less advanced 32nm+ node processes.

The latter is why this affects TSLA less (though they are ultimately still affected which I will address later). They went ahead and purchased the depressed capacity, similarly AAPL/GOOG/QCOM/MRVL all took advantage of this to buy up capacity and lock in cheaper rates for the next couple of years while autos and industrial companies were panicking about a sustained economic recession.

However this still ultimately does affect TSLA (and NIO, LI, etc that took similar approaches) in that purchasing capacity during the dip doesn't protect you from increased requirements going forward due to growth. So while they aren't needing to cut production like traditional autos that stupidly cancelled their contracts they aren't able to grow capacity because the same companies that cancelled are now willing to buy capacity at a premium and are buying everything they can.

This has some big follow-on effects for the semi-conductor industry though, especially combined with developments over the last few years w.r.t geopolitics. Firstly all the big foundries (INTC/TSM/Samsung) are building out new fabs now. These take 2-3 years to online but once they do come online we are going to see a massive supply glut which will drastically lower the prices of NAND, consumer electronics chips etc and free up the older fabs for the next gen of auto/industrial chips which will slowly upgrade from 32nm+.

The boom/bust, crunch/glut cycle is nothing new for semi-conductors but there has just been a perfect storm of factors to make this particular cycle very noticable for the first time of people outside of consumer electronics.

author: Dry_Dog_698
body:
Ok, so I have no investments in either the auto industry nor silicon.  However I looked into it and here are some reasons why the OP is an idiot.

His argument is that INTC is a good investment because of the automotive chip shortage.

1). INTC doesn’t make automobile chips

2). Neither do the car companies

3) car computer modules are created by companies who then outsource in bulk the components.  So something like Chrysler will buy a module from Bosch who will buy the from the cheapest bidder.

4) there is a chip shortage.  However the current issue is that because it’s outsourced through several rings of suppliers car manufacturers have almost no control over their supply chains and no clout over their actual producer(TSM).  So when they cancelled and then restarted their orders the auto industry set their supply chains back a few months. 

The shortage is that, several months worth of production.  It might sound big for Toyota to make 1.5m fewer cars this year.  But that’s 15%.  It’s not a total shutdown.

5). If this were an EV issue then companies that don’t really sell EVs, most of them (Nissan/Renault, Stellantis, Ford, Toyota, Honda, Mazda, etc) wouldn’t have been hit either, no?

Finally, Ford has what?  100k LiON batteries to put in cars this year?  In their production run of 7m cars?  Ford can try and blame EVs, but the truth is their whole industry blundered bigly.  Ford just blundered worse cause they’re so bad at managing supply.

You’re arguing a secular increase in chip usage due to EVs.  Hey genius, there’s a secular increase in chips due to everything.   It’s why TSM is putting $100b into capex this year.

author: tdreampo
body:
So as a person that’s been an investor for decades AND I have worked in the tech industry for decades, I personally have sold all my Intel stock. I held Intel for about fifteen years but I’m now very convinced that their glory days are behind them. They certainly will be a billion dollar company for decades to come but they are just far too behind the next big race. Here is why. 

The actual architecture and nature of the cpu race has changed. For years it was all about raw performance, we saw this with x86 architecture (which is intels bread and butter) we have seen this for 30 years, higher clock speeds, more cores. But two major shifts happened in the industry that Intel just isn’t prepared for. One is the rise of mobile devices led by the iPhone with android soon to follow. Power consumption became the driving metric for better battery life. Most mobile phones use a cpu architecture called“ARM” vs Intels x86 architecture that powers most windows devices. ARM CPU’s use considerably less power then their x86 counterparts and now that the worlds primary computer is their phone, arm has considerable market share. The next thing that happened was ARM CPU’s became incredibly powerful and could rival (and sometimes just destroy) X86 CPU’s in performance while consuming less power. The industry term now is “performance per watt” This is why Apple is switching out their entire product line to ARM even on Mac’s which over the last decade or so ran Intel CPU’s. 

Another tech shift is cloud computing with the rise of AWS, Azure and Google cloud. Electric costs are out of control for big data centers so these guys are turning to ARM CPU’s for server side work as well. This is a MASSIVE shift in the industry that no one knows about except people that work in the industry. So Intel is being directly assaulted on both the server side and the mobile side in a war that they were WAY late to the party on. I don’t see them recovering easily from this shift. 

Now of course none of this happens over night and it will probably take a decade but their hay-days are behind them. Then you look at what AMD is doing and they are actually making decent products after all these years. So even on Intels home turf they have a fierce competitor. Hope that helps.

author: Bamstradamus
body:
DDR5 news might provide a pop, but they would still have to sell the memory.  I have said it over and over on CRSR posts, this chip shortage is not ending any time soon, the vast majority of people are still waiting on GPU's to upgrade anything, especially since at higher resolutions the bottleneck moves from the CPU to the GPU, you can run 4k60 on a first gen Ryzen as long as you have a GPU capable of outputting the frames.

Add to that historically the first set of chips on a new DDR is typically slower then the previous gens top tier, the fact all RAM is essentially the same since their are only 3 major manufacturers and everyone just repackages those chips, GSkill probably outbidding everyone else for "the good chip" at the start again *seriously did any of you even build a Ryzen system, Corsair had like 4 compatible sku's for the entire 300 series chipsets life, Gskill got all the B-die*
and the fact we don't have any real world specs to work with yet I don't know anyone chomping at the bit for the DDR5 release.

I can see the news drop leading to a pop, I do not see DDR5 sales making an actual contribution to value until the NEXT set of chipsets come from AMD/Intel.

author: x_ScubaSteve_x
body:
$KLIC

We are in a massive semiconductor shortage that’s impacting nearly every industry. Companies like Intel, Samsung, TSMC are investing billions to build new factories and increase capacities. KLIC is a company that manufactures equipment used to manufacture semiconductors. They also sell their services to service, maintain, and repair their equipment.

My cost basis is about $45 right now. I’m not sure what my price target is, but I didn’t even think about selling it when it hit $75 a few days ago. I think it’s going to take years for the full semiconductor market to catch up to demand as it is only going to continue to increase globally.

$KLIC has a P/E of 17x in an industry with competitors sitting as high as 58x. Industry median is 27.9x. They have a profit margin of 20.60%, higher than any competitor in the segment. They have revenue growth of 106% TTM. Also, all 3 analyst ratings offered in TDA list it as a strong buy, so you know this shit is solid. 

I have no idea if any of the things I said line up in any way, shape, or form. I didn’t research who these guys supply to. I just figured it didn’t matter. Global shortage. Cheap. How can it possibly go tits up?

This is actually the opposite of the definition of undervalued. Undervalued means that the company should be valued more than what the stock price represents and as such it should and will go up at some point.

&#x200B;

Now, regarding Intel. I am not sure how much you follow Intel but their new processor Alder Lake will be released this year. They are finally getting into the gaming GPU market with their GPU Alchemist which is due in the beginning of 2022.

Both of these are rumored to be good and compete at the top. Intel also has a roadmap to improve even more in the gaming GPU market in the upcoming years.  

Regardless if this GPU competes at the top of the gaming GPU market, it takes market share from Nvidia and AMD and adds profits to Intel from a market they were not in at all up to this point. 

Based on older CPU prices compared to AMD, Intel also has the ability to sell cheaper than at least AMD.

Intel got a contract from the US government to build a foundry on US soil to combat the control China has on the chip market.

Intel are noticing a very massive growth potential in the automotive market with the chip shortage and are changing their factory in Ireland to manufacture chips for cars.

Intel are going to invest $95 bil in boosting up chip manufacturing in Europe.

&#x200B;

Intel is way undervalued for what they have going for them in the future.

author: NodeDotSwift
body:
Intel is struggling to compete with AMD in x86 processors, and is losing its largest exclusive PC customer, Apple, to ARM processors. That’s losing 20M mostly higher end CPUs a year by end of next year.

Apples first ARM based PC processor, the M1, is already faster than any Intel laptop processor, while using less than 1/3 the power, producing far less heat and is much cheaper to make. In the next few weeks Apple is announcing the M1x, even faster and more powerful making 95% of the lineup ARM based.

Sure, that’s just Apple but Microsoft, Google, Samsung, and Qualcomm are already working on their own ARM based processors for PCs. They will be able to achieve similar performance advantages over the ancient cruft filled x86, and in 5 years Chromebooks and Surface laptops are likely to be mostly ARM based.

But that’s not even intels biggest risk. Graviton, Amazon’s server ARM processor is already more cost effective than x86 for hosting. It’s low power/low heat means more can be fitted into server rooms. And servers are a much bigger percentage of Intel profits than PCs.

Why do i think it's likely to happen? The  new foundry.    
     
 Short term:  TSMC can't satisfy the demand     
 Long term: US government wants a reliable chip manufacturing in house. What if Taiwan was annexed? The world would be on its knees in front of China.   
    
Strong tailwind.

author: Mindless-Swordfish-7
body: Even Intel outsourced few chips manufacturing to TSMC last year due to inability to produce them in house

author: Investing8675309
body: They can’t get their fabs at par with TSM barring (1) Chinese invasion of Taiwan (2) hundreds of billions of US Gov stimulus over many years to Intel (3) paradigm shift in how semis are manufactured. People that aren’t familiar with the industry don’t seem to understand this. It will not happen.

author: ZDubzNC
body: My unpopular opinion is that Intel has the best value out of the options now. The US govt won’t let them fall behind too long with the new tensions with China and Taiwan. They have the size and ability to catch up with the cutting edge and have been taking the steps to do so.

author: MasterHand3
body: If Intel can get back on track and produce 7nm chips. Less reliance on the East the better. I would imagine IF Intel can be a real competitor again then all sales from inside the US go straight to Intel

author: robmafia
body:
intc was complacent and their sp (as bad as it's been) has been perpetually propped up by buybacks (~$20B/year).  the buybacks are over and it'll take many years before their new fabs are running.

once the market/analysts realize pat's giving them a smoke and mirrors routine, they're fucked... with the exception of the us govt bailing them out/subsidizing them bigly.

author: parsley_lover
body:
I love INTC but if they don't start innovating, they are going to get crushed. They have an ambitious roadmap but they simply can't afford delays anymore. The reason they didn't lose much marketshare was the supply problems AMD had. Same with the foundry business. They have great plans but TSMC is not a sitting duck. 
I am still hopeful though. New CEO understands that R&D is much more important than share buyback in silicon industry.

author: daaammmN
body:
It all depends on if you overpaid or not.

Intel was almost at the 80$ mark in the 2000s.

Since then it has grown a lot, but still, 20 years later and it never reached its all time high.

This just proves that you can overpay for growth.
If you are overpaying, you might not see an increase for many years to come

I haven't dug into MasterCard, but I did for Visa.

IMO, Visa (and most of the market) is overpriced. The growth that Visa is projecting (mid teens) for the next 5 years is already priced in.

If the bull market continues, the stock price might increase, but it's just a matter of time before the correction arrives and reality kicks in.

I want to own Visa, I like it very much. They have been buying back shares like crazy, which is awesome. It's on my watchlist. But it still has to drop a lot for me to be a buyer. I have no doubt that it will be a buy at some point in the future though.
